title: Sailfin eel
text:
The Sailfin eel (Paraletharchus pacificus, also known commonly as the Pacific sailfin eel in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>) is an <a href="eel">eel</a> in the family <a href="Ophichthidae">Ophichthidae</a> (worm/snake eels). It was described by <a href="Raymond%20Carroll%20Osburn">Raymond Carroll Osburn</a> and <a href="John%20Treadwell%20Nichols">John Treadwell Nichols</a> in 1916, originally under the genus "<a href="Letharchus">Letharchus</a>". It is a <a href="marine%20biology">marine</a>, <a href="tropical">tropical</a> eel which is known from the eastern central <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> (from which its <a href="Specific%20name%20%28zoology%29">species epithet</a> is derived), including <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, and <a href="Panama">Panama</a>. It is known to dwell at a depth of , and inhabits rock and sand sediments. Males can reach a maximum <a href="total%20length">total length</a> of .
Due to its wide distribution, lack of known threats, and lack of observed population decline, the <a href="IUCN%20redlist">IUCN redlist</a> currently lists the Sailfin eel as Least Concern.
